detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
This is a 3-credit intensive course that combines SPAN 101 and SPAN 102. Intended for highly motivated learners with Spanish 11 or Spanish 12 experience. 

Before registering the course, please complete Spanish Language Questionnaire to determine which course level to start: https://fhis.air.arts.ubc.ca/spanish-placement-questionnaire-tool/   

See the full course overview: https://fhis.ubc.ca/course-description/span103/   

Contact us here: https://fhis.ubc.ca/undergraduate-advising-contact-form/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Ability to communicate in everyday situations; speak and write about past events; familiarity with contemporary Swedish culture. Cultural topics include: The Nobel Prize, Sweden Day, snus (Google it!), Påskkärringar and witches, and how fun the names of your relatives are in Swedish: mormor, morfar, farmor, farfar.

Book: Rivstart, Chapters 5-8

Sample syllabus here.

Interested in other courses within the Department of Central, Eastern and Northern European Studies? Click here.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
THTR 120: Introduction to Theatre and Performance (Studies)
 
This course is an introduction to theatre and performance, as well as their concomitant academic discipline/s theatre and performance studies. Performance will be broadly construed to include aesthetic performance (theatre, performance art, music, dance, visual culture, etc.), as well as everyday performances of the self. Together, we'll ask: where and how does performance happen and what are its social, political, and historical significances? Paying close attention to questions of race, gender, sexuality, disability, Indigeneity, class, and nation as well as to theatre and performance studies braided relationship to other fields and bodies of knowledge (anthropology, feminism, queer theory, dance studies, critical race theory, queer of color critique, Black studies, sound studies, critical Indigenous studies, etc.)
We will explore how the study of performance can help us understand contemporary questions of aesthetics, politics, history, and social culture. This course will place particular emphasis on political, Indigenous, queer, feminist, and minoritarian performance.

NOTE: You must also sign up for a discussion section: D11, or D12.

If this section if FULL or BLOCKED please sign up for the corresponding wait list section. Once you have registered in the wait list there is no need to contact the department. Your registration will be switched to the parent section when space becomes available. Preference may be given to Majors, Minors, or Honours students in Theatre or Film. For more information about Department of Theatre and Film wait lists please visit: http://theatrefilm.ubc.ca/undergraduate/undergraduate-courses/how-to-wait-list-a-course/

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
